text: OK, so first I'll talk about class-switching, because it's easier. Basically, an antibody has 2 functional parts, (1) the part that binds to something (like a coronavirus spike protein) and (2) a part that determines what happens when the antibody binds (the "effector function").

elements.text: OK, so first I'll talk about class-switching, because it's easier. Basically, an antibody has 2 functional parts, (1) the part that binds to something (like a coronavirus spike protein) and (2) a part that determines what happens when the antibody binds (the "effector function").

text:
There are several different effector functions an antibody might have, depending on the type of pathogen they respond to. Some antibodies are really good at activating things like mast cells to combat parasites, some are really good at crossing epithelial barriers like into your gut, lungs, tears etc, and some are really good at floating around your blood, soaking up particles and getting cleared out of the way. Each of these types of antibody (each "class") has a different part 2.

The thing is, before a B-cell encounters an antigen, it doesn't know what kind of pathogen it belongs to, so all naive B-cells have "class M". During an infection, responding B-cells are educated about what kind of pathogen is present, and are able to switch their  effector domain to the one best suited for the pathogen they're responding to. That's class switching

text: So a memory B-cell that was educated during a coronavirus infection (or vaccination, presumably) will already have the correct effector function in place, it doesn't need to relearn which one is best.

text:
Affinity maturation is a bit more complicated. Understanding it depends on knowing that every naive B-cell in your body has a unique and randomized binding domain. There's no way for a B-cell to know ahead of time what it binds to, or how well it will bind. The vast majority of B-cells will never bind to anything.

But during an infection, you usually have at least a couple of B-cells that bind a little bit. When they bind, they undergo "affinity maturation," where their binding domain is progressively mutated. This happens over multiple rounds, and in each round, the mutants that bind best are selected for continued maturation.

Best way to think of it is like rapid, directed evolution of the binding domain.

text:
One example that's not quite the same thing, but is relevant in vaccine design, which is that certain antigens of interest are hard to direct responses against, possibly due the the fact that other epitopes "soak up" all of the T-cell help required for affinity maturation.

Best example of this I can think of is flu HA - we typically make responses against the highly variable head portion rather than the more conserved stalk. If we could direct responses to the latter, we'd have much more universal vaccines
